intro: Corchorus kirkii, commonly known as the African broomrape, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa. It is a herbaceous annual that lacks chlorophyll and relies on parasitic relationships with other plants for nutrients. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in spikes, and its seeds are enclosed in capsules. It is often found in disturbed soils and can be invasive in certain regions. Botanically, it is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus.
